article.headline: As Trump trails in national polls, his new campaign manager says the surveys âkeep getting it wrongâ
article.body: “ âNational polls keep getting it wrong.â ” â Bill Stepien, Trumpâs campaign manager The line above came Friday afternoon from Bill Stepien, President Donald Trumpâs new campaign manager, as he projected confidence about the state of the White House race amid a range of polls showing sizable leads for Democratic challenger Joe Biden. Stepien, a veteran Republican operative, became the manager of Trumpâs re-election campaign last week, replacing Brad Parscale, who remains with the campaign. Two recent national surveys âprovide a sample that is 27% less Republican than showed up at the polls in the last presidential election â 27% less Republican,â Stepien said during a conference call with reporters. âThatâs why weâre not going to spend a lot of time here â any time at all â talking further about national polls, and itâs why, as I said before, we donât pay a lot of attention to them day to day here in the campaign.â He said pollsters survey registered voters, âwhich never resembles the actual turnout of the election,â and he said they draw on states that donât âeven come close to being a part of the battleground map.â The campaign manager talked up Trumpâs chances of getting the 270 electoral votes needed to win Novemberâs presidential election. âWe think that there isnât just a pathway to 270 but multiple pathways to 270,â he said, as he suggested there were favorable trends in a number of swing states. âThe president is polling better in Arizona among key demographics now than where he was four years ago,â Stepien said. Minnesota is âa state that the president lost by just 44,000 votes, 1.5% four years ago,â he also said. âSo if people are going to talk about Pennsylvania as a pickup opportunity for Joe Biden, seems only fair that Minnesota should get that same treatment coming the other way.â âBottom line is building off of the 2016 map, I think there are several offensive opportunities in play for the presidentâs campaign, and we have the unique luxury of having the ability to expand our map, expand our electoral path,â the campaign manager told reporters. In a RealClearPolitics moving average of national polls as of Friday, Biden drew support of 49.6% of voters, ahead of Trumpâs 40.9%. Besides polls, a campaignâs financial reports are a closely watched measure of viability, and Bidenâs war chest is catching up to Trumpâs. The president also often touts the performance of the stock market SPX, +0.87% Â DJIA, +0.56%, but it has been trading below its February peaks amid worries over the coronavirus pandemicâs economic effects.
